text: forty years ago man first set foot on
the surface of the Moon there's no movie
that captures the awe of that moment and
of space travel of standing in front of
the vastness of the universe quite as
powerfully as Stanley Kubrick's sublime
2001 a Space Odyssey this movie is a
tour de force of widescreen visual
compositions elegant and fluid
camerawork exquisite production design
and mind-blowing special effects human
characters really fade into the
background they're upstaged above all by
the spaceships themselves as they're
filmed from within and from without
and of course the most fascinating
character in this movie is a machine who
can forget Hal 9000 the lovable computer
whose relationship with astronaut Dave
Bowman is really at the dramatic heart
of 2001 my mind is going
I can feel it this movie based on a
novel by arthur c clarke has two levels
of plot one of which is fairly trivial
it involves the details of the American
astronauts journey into outer space
the real story takes place on the scale
of cosmic history and it involves
nothing less than the evolution of
consciousness itself the movie begins in
prehistory on the African savanna where
in the shadow of a mysterious monolith
our proto-human ancestors discover the
use of tools
it then leaps ahead far into the future
which from where we sit now is the past
when two more mana lists have been
discovered one on the surface of the
Moon and the other on the outskirts of
Jupiter
but what evolutionary leap do these
indicate with our tools maybe computers
achieve their own self-consciousness and
start to take over our lives open the
pod bay doors help I'm sorry Dave I'm
afraid I can't do that well some alien
life force kidnapped our space travelers
and hold them hostage in futuristic
hotel rooms decorated with antique
French furniture will we transcend the
limits finally of time and space
these are the questions that fans of
2001 have been arguing about for more
than 40 years and these arguments will
never end why should they
you
you
